text: So it’s Saint Patrick’s Day weekend
and you’re having a few drinks with friends.

Don’t make the incredibly stupid
decision to get behind the wheel.
If you do, you might see those blue lights
in your rear-view mirror, and an officer
pulling out one of these (portable breath test).
Think you can beat the test?
Forget about it,
because chemistry will land you in ‘cuffs.
We asked corporal mike rose of the Prince Georges
County Maryland police to demonstrate an alcosensor,
one major types of breath testers in use today.

“There’s a 1cc breath sample
that’s taken by the instrument.
It’s placed into what is called a fuel cell.
This fuel cell, all it does is react with alcohol.
And there’s an electrical discharge
that’ll take place from that fuel cell
and there’s a direct proportion depending on
the amount of alcohol that’s in the breath sample
to how much electricity will come out."
But how do I know it’s accurate,
your drunk self is saying.
The breath testers are calibrated with
a gas mix that mimics someone blowing a point
oh-eight, so there’s no guessing involved.
These field units are accurate enough where
a police officer can confirm that you probably
shouldn’t be behind a wheel, at which point
they bring you in to the station for a breath
test with a full-size, higher accuracy unit.

But how does your breath give away
how much alcohol is in your body?
“With your breath, there’s a direct correlation
between the percentage of alcohol that’s in your
blood and the breath that’s expelled. There’s a
21-hundred to one ratio there. We can measure the
amount of the air and the air is going to have
the same proportion of alcohol in the air that’s
coming back out as what’s in the blood
that’s flowing through your body.”
It turns out that once ethanol,
the alcohol found in beer, wine and liquor,
is absorbed by your stomach and moves through
your liver and bloodstream, a tiny fraction
of it makes its way to your lungs.
And even if you’re just under the legal limit,
chances are you won’t pass a field sobriety test.
Don’t try to wait it out either.
Your body can only metabolize about three-quarters
of one regular drink per hour, so you’ll be
waiting a while if you’re trying to sober up.
So drink your green beer, have a good time,
but remember the bottom line:
Bring a designated driver that will blow one of these
(show 0.00)
so you don’t end up in one of these (show cop car).
That’s it for this week.
Once you get rid of that hangover, which
by the way you can learn about here, why not subscribe
to get more chemistry fun from ACS each week.
